prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Factors militating against transfer—Opposition of parties

para.paratext: The Panel considers, though is not bound by, the view of the parties towards transfer. Just as the preference of the parties favoring transfer will be considered by the Panel,[1] opposition to transfer by the parties will be given some weight by the Panel.[2] Opposition of the parties may be persuasive evidence that the statutory requirement that transfer be “for the convenience of the parties and witnesses” would not be met by transfer.[3]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See In re Brown Co. Securities Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 307, 308 (J.P.M.L. 1971). Accord In re Chicken Broiler Antitrust Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 788 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Warhead Explosion Aboard USS Newport News on October 1, 1972, 411 F. Supp. 790 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Palizzio, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 241 (J.P.M.L. 1976). See § 5:20.

See, e.g., In re Healthextras Ins. Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (Panel notes that all defendants oppose transfer); In re Scientific Drilling Intern., Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (only 2 actions, both plaintiffs oppose centralization); In re Amazon.com, Inc., Fulfillment Center Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2014) (some plaintiffs and all defendants oppose transfer); In re Urban Outfitters Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation, 987 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2013) (all plaintiffs oppose transfer); In re Mortgage Lender Force-Placed Ins. Litigation, 895 F. Supp. 2d 1352 (J.P.M.L. 2012); In re Ocala Funding, LLC, Commercial Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1332 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (all parties except movant oppose transfer; centralization denied); In re Property Assessed Clean Energy (PACE) Programs Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1345 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (noting that most parties oppose transfer); In re Schneider National Carriers, Inc. Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 763 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Table Saw Products Liability Litigation, 641 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2009) (noting that all defendants in 42 actions oppose transfer); In re Tyson Foods, Inc., Meat Processing Facilities Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (Panel notes all plaintiffs oppose transfer); In re Title Ins. Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) & Antitrust Litigation, 560 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (all parties oppose transfer); In re Insurance Companies “Silent” Preferred Provider Organization (PPO) Litigation, 517 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (all responding parties oppost transfer); In re Lycoming Crankshaft Products Liability Litigation, 473 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (all plaintiffs oppose transfer); In re Pullen & Associates, LLC, Brokered Group Health Plans Litigation, 366 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (all plaintiffs oppose transfer; transfer denied); In re Asbestos School Products Liability Litigation, 606 F. Supp. 713 (J.P.M.L. 1985); Dardar v. State of La., 322 F. Supp. 1115 (E.D. La. 1971), judgment aff'd, 447 F.2d 952 (5th Cir. 1971), cert. denied, 405 U.S. 918, 92 S. Ct. 943, 30 L. Ed. 2d 788 (1972) (unanimous opposition). See also Giuliano v. MB Solutions Second Acquisition Corp. (In re National Arbitration Forum Trade Practices Litigation), 729 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2010) (Panel notes opposition of all parties in denying motion to vacate conditional transfer order.).
See 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a). The statute is reprinted in § 3:19.
